results.title: Queen Victoria's empire
results.creator_credit: Paul Bryers, Paul Burgess, Brook Lapping, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
At the time of Queen Victoria’s birth in 1819 England was an agrarian society; within a few short decades this nation would be transformed into an industrial superpower, with an empire spanning the globes. This captivating four part series covers the transition with historical re-enactments, stills and interviews with historians, providing a portrait of Queen Victoria and British imperialism. Episode 1. “Engines of change”: Explores the changes brought to Britain by the industrial revolution, urban migration, overcrowding, extremes in poverty and pollution of the 1840s and Prince Albert’s role. Episode 2. “Passage to India”: In the 1850s, as steamships take British goods around the globe, tensions rise in India with a clash of Victorian values and Indian culture, resulting in the Great Mutiny and Cawnpore massacre of 1857; also covers the Crimean War and the death of Prince Albert. Episode 3. “The Moral Crusade”: By 1861 Britain is the wealthiest and most powerful nation on earth; David Livingstone’s explorations of the African interior fascinate the British public; Disraeli and Gladstone battle for control of the government; colonisation of Africa begins. Episode 4. “The scramble for Africa”: The Suez Canal is threatened by a holy war in the Sudan; Cecil Rhodes prospects diamond deposits in South Africa and asserts regional control; the Boer War leads to devastating British losses; Queen Victoria’s death marks the end of an era.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Bryers, Paul Burgess, Brook Lapping, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)

results.title: Martin Luther
results.creator_credit: Cassian Harrison, Richard Bradley, Devillier Donegan Enterprises, Lion Television and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Born in Germany at the height of the Black Death, Martin Luther was raised in a Europe dominated spiritually, economically and politically by the Roman Catholic Church. This two part series, narrated by Liam Neeson, explores the life of this important revolutionary thinker. In episode one, “Driven To Defiance”, we are taken through Luther’s early childhood and years as a student where his deepening spiritual faith leads him to a vocation as a monk. But on making a pilgrimage to the Vatican in Rome, he discovers a corrupt and bloated Church and a degenerate and cynical priesthood. The experience leads him to the writing of the 95 Theses, a call to arms against religious corruption and a return to the gospels of Jesus Christ. Central to the theses is Luther’s attack on the Catholic Church’s selling of Indulgence which are meant to ensure a dying person’s passage to Heaven. In calling for a spiritual renewal of Christianity, Luther’s 95 Theses lay the foundations for Protestantism. In episode two, “The Reluctant Revolutionary”, the Catholic Church responds to Luther’s attacks by charging him with heresy. But a fortunate historic confluence - the invention of the printing press - allows for the first time the wide dissemination of Luther’s ideas and beliefs which find popular support all across Europe. Luther attacks the Church hierarchy at his trial and his protests leads to revolutionary upheaval across the continent. The episode examines both Luther’s radical impact but also his refusal to support the peasant revolutionaries inspired by his rhetoric. Luther can imagine a spiritual revolutionary order but not an economic revolution. His vehement and ruthless attacks against the poor, the peasantry and against the Jews will resonate in Protestantism through the ages and lead to a tension in the Christian faiths which will see Catholicism brave the Reformation and paradoxically regain strength in the modern world as the Christian Church for the poor and the oppressed. Whatever the contradictions of his faith and life, the religious revolution inspired by Luther is undoubtedly one of the greatest singular moments in European history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cassian Harrison, Richard Bradley, Devillier Donegan Enterprises, Lion Television and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)

results.title: The Roman empire in the first century
results.creator_credit: Lyn Goldfarb, Margaret Koval, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
Narrated by Sigourney Weaver, these four episodes focus on the rise of the Roman Empire. In episode one, “Order from Chaos” the Roman Republic has collapsed into the century-long chaos of civil war. Julius Caesar’s victories have led to the expansion of the Empire. But with Caesar’s murder in the senate, Augustus is made Emperor and the beginning of a hereditary dictatorship is put in place. Augustus’ rule results in the further expansion of the Empire and the rise of Roman art and architecture but his sometimes ruthless squashing of enemies foretell the problems that will lie ahead for the empire. In episode two, “Years of Trial”, we begin with the death of Augustus in 14 AD. Tiberius becomes emperor and though initially popular, he soon shows signs of tyranny. The fortunes of Roman citizenship are viewed through the eyes of the poet Ovid. The life of Roman citizens becomes even more horrific with the ascendancy of Caligula as Emperor, whose madness manifests itself in the belief that he is a God and whose excesses become increasingly sadistic and dangerous for Rome. In the Eastern province of Judaea a religious prophet named Jesus brings Roman occupation and Jewish resistance to loggerheads. In episode three, “Winds of Change”, the terror of Caligula’s reign is replaced by the provident and wise rule of Claudius. But the decadence of hereditary rule results in his murder by his unscrupulous wife who places her son Nero on the throne. The new Emperor is tutored by the Stoic philosopher, Senenca. By witnessing the accommodations to power that Seneca makes - at odds with his egalitarian philosophy - we witness the tensions of Roman citizenship, with a past built on Republican grandeur and a present built on hereditary empire. At the outposts of the empire, the English warrior queen Boudicca (Bodicea) wars against the Romans who massacred her family and kin, and in Judaea the Jewish zealot Saul is converted to Christianity, and as Saint Paul begins a missionary life that will see Christianity spread through the Roman Empire. In the final episode, “Years of Eruption”, the city of Rome is besieged by fire and Nero is put to death for his calamitous excesses. A new period of civil wars begins and Vestpatian is finally made Emperor. The kingdom of Judaea is crushed and the Temple in Jerusalem is destroyed. The city of Pompeii is buried by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius but with its excavation in the 1600s we have a permanent record of Roman art and life: that of the nobles and that of the slaves, that of the women and of the men. The episode ends with the ascendancy of Trajan to the throne of Emperor.

results.title: Islam: empire of faith
results.creator_credit: Robert H Gardner, Devillier Donegan Enterprises, Gardner Films and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
This three part history of Islam is narrated by Ben Kingsley. In episode 1, “The Messenger”, we are introduced to pre-monotheistic Arab society. In a desert world consisting of warring nomadic tribes, differences were only put aside when the tribes congregated in the holy city of Mecca to worship their individual gods and totems. From this centre of trade and religion, the Prophet Muhammad first began to receive visions from the one God. Though initially exiled by his opponents, Muhammad finds refuge in the oasis of Medina, and there he builds up a strong and loyal following united, for the first time, not by blood but by faith. Having conquered the Meccan forces sent to vanquish him and his followers, Muhammad triumphantly returned to Mecca, smashed the idols and proclaimed his divine message. In episode 2, “The Awakening”, the recording of the Prophet’s vision in the Koran sees the spread of Islam throughout the Arabian peninsula, and then to Persia, India, North African and Southern Europe and the Balkans. The religion leads to a democratisation of society and a flourishing of art, architecture, philosophy and science as the Muslim scholars integrate the thoughts of the ancient Greeks with the philosophy arising from Islam. The Islamic Empire is, however, threatened by the Crusades initiated by the fundamentalist European Christians, and then further dispersed by the massacres and invasions of the Mongol Empire. In episode 3, “The Ottomans”, we see how the Islamic world has been transformed by the Mongol invasion and the Mongols in turn have been transformed by their conversion to Islam. Nomadic tribes from Anatolia, enlisted to combat the Mongols, unite and form the beginning of the Ottoman Empire. One of the world’s largest empires, the Ottomans move into Christian Europe and take as their seat the Byzantine city of Constantinople. From the renamed city, Istanbul, the Ottomans create a flourishing art and culture. The episode concentrates on the career of Suleyman the Magnificent, the most talented, important and fierce of the Ottoman Sultans.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert H Gardner, Devillier Donegan Enterprises, Gardner Films and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)

In episode 2, “The Awakening”, the recording of the Prophet’s vision in the Koran sees the spread of Islam throughout the Arabian peninsula, and then to Persia, India, North African and Southern Europe and the Balkans. The religion leads to a democratisation of society and a flourishing of art, architecture, philosophy and science as the Muslim scholars integrate the thoughts of the ancient Greeks with the philosophy arising from Islam. The Islamic Empire is, however, threatened by the Crusades initiated by the fundamentalist European Christians, and then further dispersed by the massacres and invasions of the Mongol Empire. In episode 3, “The Ottomans”, we see how the Islamic world has been transformed by the Mongol invasion and the Mongols in turn have been transformed by their conversion to Islam. Nomadic tribes from Anatolia, enlisted to combat the Mongols, unite and form the beginning of the Ottoman Empire. One of the world’s largest empires, the Ottomans move into Christian Europe and take as their seat the Byzantine city of Constantinople. From the renamed city, Istanbul, the Ottomans create a flourishing art and culture. The episode concentrates on the career of Suleyman the Magnificent, the most talented, important and fierce of the Ottoman Sultans.

results.title: Queer as folk. Series 01. Eps. 01-08 [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Charles McDougall, Sarah Harding, Nicola Shindler, Channel Four and Red Productions
results.brief_description: Season one of the uncompromising 8 part British series which chronicles the hedonistic lifestyle and sexual exploits of a group of 20 something single gay men. ‘Episode one’ (director Charles McDougall): The series opens with the Dr. Who obsessed Vince Tyler (Craig Kelly) giving us a run down of what happens on a regular night out with his friends on Canal street, a popular gay strip in London. We are introduced to his egotistical and unscrupulous best friend, Stuart Jones (Aiden Gillen), who has just scored his latest conquest, the 15 year old and recently ‘out’, Nathan Maloney (Charlie Hunnman). Initially just a one night stand for Stuart, Nathan becomes infatuated with him, much to Vince’s displeasure who harbors his own secret crush for his best friend. ‘Episode two’ (director Charles McDougall): Vince is not ‘out’ at work, which leads to an awkward situation with one of his female co-workers. Nathan’s mother discovers gay pornography in his bedroom. Stewart brings his new born baby home from the hospital which he is co-parenting with a lesbian couple. ‘Episode three’ (director Charles McDougall): Nathan - still obsessed with Stuart, goes to Canal street with his best friend Donna (Carla Henry) to find him. Stuart, however, goes home with two other men that night. Vince’s friend Phil (Jason Merrells) picks up a stranger with deadly consequences. ‘Episode four’ (director Charles McDougall): Vince and Stuart attend Phil’s funeral, where Vince meets Cameron (Peter O’Brien). Nathan runs away from home when his mother confronts him about his sexuality and ends up at Vince’s mothers house. ‘Episode five’ (director Sarah Harding): Vince and Cameron go on a date. Stuart learns from his sister Janice (Caroline O’Neill) that their parents are getting divorced. ‘Episode six’ (director Sarah Harding): Stuart unsuccessfully tries to smooth out Nathan’s troubled family situation. Cameron meets Vince’s mother (Denise Black). ‘Episode seven’ (director Sarah Harding): Stuart helps throw a surprise party for Vince’s 30th birthday, then tries to sabotage Vince and Cameron’s relationship. ‘Episode eight’ (director Sarah Harding): Stuart’s world begins to crumble around him. Vince realises that Cameron’s hold on him is too restricting. Nathan decides to run away from home. (Written by Russell T Davies)

results.title: Queen Kat, Carmel & St Jude: Parts 3-4: Spring-Summer
results.creator_credit: Moira Moss, Chris Warner, ABC-TV (Australia), Film Finance Corporation Australia, Film Victoria and Trout Films
results.brief_description: Based on Maureen McCarthy’s popular novel “Queen Kat, Carmel & St Jude get a life”, this made for television mini-series will strike a chord with anyone who has made the transition from country to city, high school to university, or just struggling to find themselves. There are four episodes in the series - each from the perspective of one of the three housemates - the final episode draws together the threads of the burgeoning friendship. “Spring: Chapter three: Kat.” Kat is having problems with boyfriend Dion (Simon Bossell) after she sits for a series of nude photographs. Things escalate when Dion plants drugs on Kat and she is arrested by the police and taken in for questioning. She is faced with the moral dilemma of deciding between co-operating with the police and giving Dion up, or remaining quiet, thus jeopardising her law career. Carmel is still pining over Anton but her emotions are placed on hold when she returns home to her terminally ill mother. Her absence gives Kat and Jude time to bond. Are the housemates becoming friends? “Winter: Chapter four: Manella.” Everyone gathers at Mrs McCaffrey’s funeral and Carmel has to reach a decision about her future; personal dreams or family loyalty, and whether she loves unfaithful Anton. Her family, along with some help from Kat, struggles to save the farm from being taken over. Results are in and there is a bonfire party to celebrate. Written by Meaghan Smith.

results.title: Queen Kat, Carmel & St Jude. Parts 1-2: Autumn-Winter
results.creator_credit: Moira Moss, Chris Warner, ABC-TV (Australia), Film Finance Corporation Australia, Film Victoria and Trout Films
results.brief_description: Based on Maureen McCarthy’s popular novel “Queen Kat, Carmel & St Jude get a life”, this made for television mini-series will strike a chord with anyone who has made the transition from country to city, high school to university, or just struggling to find themselves. There are four episodes in the series - each from the perspective of one of the three housemates - the final episode draws the threads together of the burgeoning friendship. “Autumn: Chapter one: Carmel.” Carmel McCaffrey (Alicia Gardiner), gifted singer, pianist and only daughter in a sheep farming family is facing resistance from her mother who is reluctant for her to go to university, citing she is a country girl like her mother and the family cannot afford for her to go: only her brother Vince (Ben Mendelsohn) seems to be on her side. Carmel makes it to Melbourne however and moves in with law student “Princess” Kat (Elissa Elliot), and down to earth Jude (Ingrid Ruz). Carmel struggles with her financial situation, has a palpably uncomfortable presentation, and after questioning her choice of career, drops out and returns briefly to Manella. She also meets Anton (Justin Smith). “Winter: Chapter two: Jude.” Med student Jude is following in the professional and political path of her deceased father Carlos who died as a political prisoner in Chile, much to the chagrin of her mother. Jude is plagued by memories she cannot suppress of her absent father and seeks solace in the arms of the married Eduardo. Carmel reluctantly makes her first public appearance, no thanks to a surprise visit by her mother. Written by Meaghan Smith.

results.title: Queer as folk 2. What the folk...?
results.creator_credit: Nicola Shindler, Russell T. Davies, Menhaj Huda, Channel Four and Red Productions
results.brief_description: Follow up to the controversial British series which follows the trials and sexual exploits of a group of gay men in London. This second series was created as a one off finale and re-teams the three main protagonists from the first season. The hedonistic Stuart (Aidan Gillan), his long suffering best friend Vince (Craig Kelly), and the recently ‘out’ teenager Nathan (Charlie Hunnam). “Queer as folk 2” still focuses on the same milieu of Canal street, the gay district of the first series, but this time around centers on the relationship between Vince and Stuart. Will the two best friends finally consummate their relationship? Will Stuart come out to his parents? Will the impressionistic Nathan finally get over Stuart or follow in his footsteps? Also included is “What the folk…?” (25 mins), a short documentary on the making of the infamous series featuring interviews with the leads and writer Russell T. Davies. Cast includes Denise Black, Antony Cotton and Andy Devine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicola Shindler, Russell T. Davies, Menhaj Huda, Channel Four and Red Productions

results.title: Quebec: duplessis et apres...
results.creator_credit: Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film establishes a parallel between the 1970 electoral campaign in Quebec and the 1936 campaign dominated by Maurice Duplessis. It shows the hope but also the uncertainty that existed in 1970. Had the Quiet Revolution really changed things in Quebec? Was it possible that a new leader would emerge on the political scene?

results.title: Purple haze
results.creator_credit: Ian Stevenson, Katherine Hynes, Rachael Hynes and Bondi Beech
results.brief_description: This documentary follows the story of 5 Jacaranda Queen candidates in the country town of Grafton, NSW, before and after the crowning. It examines all the trials and tribulations of preparing for the ceremony and coping with not only losing, but winning. Their candid experience is reflected against the background of Grafton, a town living through tough economic times, the community expectation of the events, and the impact or relevance it has on their lives. Produced with assistance from the Australian Film Finance Corporation.
